the United States Electoral College be the institution that elect the President and Vice President of the United States every four year . Citizens of the United States do not directly elect the president or the vice president ; instead , these voter directly elect designate intermediary call `` elector , '' who almost always have pledge to vote for particular presidential and vice presidential candidate -lrb- though unpledged elector be possible -rrb- and who be themselves select accord to the particular law of each state . elector be apportion to each of the 50 state as well as to the District of Columbia -lrb- also know as Washington , D.C. -rrb- . the number of elector in each state be equal to the number of member of Congress to which the state be entitle , while the twenty-third amendment grant the District of Columbia the same number of elector as the least populous state , currently three . therefore , there be currently 538 elector , correspond to the 435 representative and 100 senator , plus the three additional elector from the District of Columbia . the Constitution bar any federal official , elect or appoint , from be a elector .

the Constitutional Convention in 1787 use the Virginia Plan as the basis for discussion , as the Virginia delegation have propose it first . the Virginia Plan call for the Congress to elect the president . Delegates from a majority of state agree to this mode of election . however , the Committee of eleven , form to work out various detail include the mode of election of the president , recommend instead that the election be by a group of people apportion among the state in the same number as they representative in Congress -lrb- the formula for which have be resolve in lengthy debate result in the Connecticut compromise and three-fifths compromise -rrb- , but choose by each state `` in such manner as its Legislature may direct '' . Committee member Gouverneur Morris explain the reason for the change ; among other , there be fear of `` intrigue '' if the president be choose by a small group of man who meet together regularly , as well as concern for the independence of the president if he be elect by the Congress . 
the Constitutional Convention in 1787 use the Virginia Plan as the basis for discussion , as the Virginia delegation have propose it first . the Virginia Plan call for the Congress to elect the president . Delegates from a majority of state agree to this mode of election . however , the Committee of eleven , form to work out various detail include the mode of election of the president , recommend instead that the election be by a group of people apportion among the state in the same number as they representative in Congress -lrb- the formula for which have be resolve in lengthy debate result in the Connecticut compromise and three-fifths compromise -rrb- , but choose by each state `` in such manner as its Legislature may direct '' . Committee member Gouverneur Morris explain the reason for the change ; among other , there be fear of `` intrigue '' if the president be choose by a small group of man who meet together regularly , as well as concern for the independence of the president if he be elect by the Congress . some delegate , include James Wilson and James Madison , prefer popular election of the executive . 
the Constitutional Convention in 1787 use the Virginia Plan as the basis for discussion , as the Virginia delegation have propose it first . the Virginia Plan call for the Congress to elect the president . Delegates from a majority of state agree to this mode of election . however , the Committee of eleven , form to work out various detail include the mode of election of the president , recommend instead that the election be by a group of people apportion among the state in the same number as they representative in Congress -lrb- the formula for which have be resolve in lengthy debate result in the Connecticut compromise and three-fifths compromise -rrb- , but choose by each state `` in such manner as its Legislature may direct '' . Committee member Gouverneur Morris explain the reason for the change ; among other , there be fear of `` intrigue '' if the president be choose by a small group of man who meet together regularly , as well as concern for the independence of the president if he be elect by the Congress . some delegate , include James Wilson and James Madison , prefer popular election of the executive . Madison acknowledge that while a popular vote would be ideal , it would be difficult to get consensus on the proposal give the prevalence of slavery in the South : 
there be one difficulty however of a serious nature attend a immediate choice by the people . 
there be one difficulty however of a serious nature attend a immediate choice by the people . the right of suffrage be much more diffusive in the northern than the Southern States ; and the latter could have no influence in the election on the score of negro . 
there be one difficulty however of a serious nature attend a immediate choice by the people . the right of suffrage be much more diffusive in the northern than the Southern States ; and the latter could have no influence in the election on the score of negro . the substitution of elector obviate this difficulty and seem on the whole to be liable to the fewest objection .

the Convention approve the Committee 's Electoral College proposal , with minor modification , on September 6 , 1787 . Delegates from the small state generally favor the Electoral College out of concern that the large state would otherwise control presidential election .

in the Federalist Papers , James Madison explain he view on the selection of the president and the Constitution . in Federalist No. 39 , Madison argue that the Constitution be design to be a mixture of state-based and population-based government . Congress would have two house : the state-based Senate and the population-based House of Representatives . meanwhile , the president would be elect by a mixture of the two mode . additionally , in the Federalist no. 10 , James Madison argue against `` a interested and overbearing majority '' and the `` mischief of faction '' in a electoral system . he define a faction as `` a number of citizen whether amount to a majority or minority of the whole , who be unite and actuate by some common impulse of passion , or of interest , adverse to the rights of other citizen , or to the permanent and aggregate interest of the community . in the Federalist Papers , James Madison explain he view on the selection of the president and the Constitution . in Federalist No. 39 , Madison argue that the Constitution be design to be a mixture of state-based and population-based government . Congress would have two house : the state-based Senate and the population-based House of Representatives . meanwhile , the president would be elect by a mixture of the two mode . additionally , in the Federalist no. 10 , James Madison argue against `` a interested and overbearing majority '' and the `` mischief of faction '' in a electoral system . he define a faction as `` a number of citizen whether amount to a majority or minority of the whole , who be unite and actuate by some common impulse of passion , or of interest , adverse to the rights of other citizen , or to the permanent and aggregate interest of the community . '' republican government -lrb- i.e. , federalism , as oppose to direct democracy -rrb- , with its varied distribution of voter rights and power , would countervail against faction . 
in the Federalist Papers , James Madison explain he view on the selection of the president and the Constitution . in Federalist No. 39 , Madison argue that the Constitution be design to be a mixture of state-based and population-based government . Congress would have two house : the state-based Senate and the population-based House of Representatives . meanwhile , the president would be elect by a mixture of the two mode . additionally , in the Federalist no. 10 , James Madison argue against `` a interested and overbearing majority '' and the `` mischief of faction '' in a electoral system . he define a faction as `` a number of citizen whether amount to a majority or minority of the whole , who be unite and actuate by some common impulse of passion , or of interest , adverse to the rights of other citizen , or to the permanent and aggregate interest of the community . '' republican government -lrb- i.e. , federalism , as oppose to direct democracy -rrb- , with its varied distribution of voter rights and power , would countervail against faction . Madison further postulate in the Federalist no. 10 that the greater the population and expanse of the Republic , the more difficulty faction would face in organize due to such issue as sectionalism .

although the United States Constitution refer to `` elector '' and `` elector '' , neither the phrase `` Electoral College '' nor any other name be use to describe the elector collectively . it be not until the early 19th century that the name `` Electoral College '' come into general usage as the collective designation for the elector select to cast vote for president and vice president . 
although the United States Constitution refer to `` elector '' and `` elector '' , neither the phrase `` Electoral College '' nor any other name be use to describe the elector collectively . it be not until the early 19th century that the name `` Electoral College '' come into general usage as the collective designation for the elector select to cast vote for president and vice president . it be first write into federal law in 1845 and today the term appear in 3 U.S.C.  4 , in the section head and in the text as `` college of elector '' .

== procedure == 
=== eligibility requirement === 
Article two of the United States Constitution stipulate that for a person to serve as President , the individual must be a natural-born citizen of the United States , at least 35 year old , and a resident of the United States for a period of no less than 14 year . 
Article two of the United States Constitution stipulate that for a person to serve as President , the individual must be a natural-born citizen of the United States , at least 35 year old , and a resident of the United States for a period of no less than 14 year . a candidate may start run he or she campaign early before turn 35 year old or complete 14 year of residency , but must meet the age and residency requirement by Inauguration Day . 
Article two of the United States Constitution stipulate that for a person to serve as President , the individual must be a natural-born citizen of the United States , at least 35 year old , and a resident of the United States for a period of no less than 14 year . a candidate may start run he or she campaign early before turn 35 year old or complete 14 year of residency , but must meet the age and residency requirement by Inauguration Day . the twenty-second amendment to the Constitution also set a term limit : a President can not be elect to more than two term . 
the U.S. Constitution also have two provision that apply to all federal office in general , not just the presidency . 
the U.S. Constitution also have two provision that apply to all federal office in general , not just the presidency . Article I , Section 3 , clause 7 state that if the U.S. Congress convict any officer on impeachment , they may also bar that person from hold any public office in the future . 
the U.S. Constitution also have two provision that apply to all federal office in general , not just the presidency . Article I , Section 3 , clause 7 state that if the U.S. Congress convict any officer on impeachment , they may also bar that person from hold any public office in the future . and Section 3 of the fourteenth amendment prohibit the election to any federal office of any person who have previously hold any federal or state office and then engage in insurrection , rebellion or treason ; this disqualification can be waive if such a individual gain the consent of two-third of both house of Congress . 
in addition , the Twelfth Amendment establish that the Vice-President must meet all of the qualification of be a President . 
although not a mandatory requirement , Federal campaign finance law include the Federal Election Campaign Act state that a candidate who intend to receive contribution aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 or make expenditure aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 , among other , must first file a statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission . 
although not a mandatory requirement , Federal campaign finance law include the Federal Election Campaign Act state that a candidate who intend to receive contribution aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 or make expenditure aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 , among other , must first file a statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission . this have lead presidential candidate , especially member from the two major political party , to officially announce they intention to run as early as the spring of the previous calendar year so they can start raise or spend the money need for they nationwide campaign . 
although not a mandatory requirement , Federal campaign finance law include the Federal Election Campaign Act state that a candidate who intend to receive contribution aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 or make expenditure aggregate in excess of $ 5,000 , among other , must first file a statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission . this have lead presidential candidate , especially member from the two major political party , to officially announce they intention to run as early as the spring of the previous calendar year so they can start raise or spend the money need for they nationwide campaign . potential candidate usually form exploratory committee even earlier to determine the feasibility of they actually run . 
=== nominating process === 
the modern nominating process of U.S. presidential election currently consist of two major part : a series of presidential primary election and caucus hold in each state , and the presidential nominating convention hold by each political party . 
the modern nominating process of U.S. presidential election currently consist of two major part : a series of presidential primary election and caucus hold in each state , and the presidential nominating convention hold by each political party . this process be never include in the United States Constitution , and thus evolve over time by the political party to clear the field of candidate . 
the primary election be run by state and local government , while the caucus be organize directly by the political party . 
the primary election be run by state and local government , while the caucus be organize directly by the political party . some state hold only primary election , some hold only caucus , and other use a combination of both . 
the primary election be run by state and local government , while the caucus be organize directly by the political party . some state hold only primary election , some hold only caucus , and other use a combination of both . these primary and caucus be stagger generally between January and June before the federal election , with Iowa and New Hampshire traditionally hold the first presidential state caucus and primary , respectively . 
like the general election , presidential caucus or primary be indirect election . 
like the general election , presidential caucus or primary be indirect election . the major political party officially vote for they presidential candidate at they respective nominating convention , usually all hold in the summer before the federal election . 
like the general election , presidential caucus or primary be indirect election . the major political party officially vote for they presidential candidate at they respective nominating convention , usually all hold in the summer before the federal election . depend on each state 's law and state 's political party rule , when voter cast ballot for a candidate in a presidential caucus or primary , they may be vote to award delegate `` bind '' to vote for a candidate at the presidential nominating convention , or they may simply be express a opinion that the state party be not bind to follow in select delegate to they respective national convention . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . furthermore , each political party can determine how many delegate to allocate to each state and territory . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . furthermore , each political party can determine how many delegate to allocate to each state and territory . in 2012 for example , the democratic and republican party convention each use two different formula to allocate delegate . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . furthermore , each political party can determine how many delegate to allocate to each state and territory . in 2012 for example , the democratic and republican party convention each use two different formula to allocate delegate . the Democrats base theirs on two main factor : -lrb- 1 -rrb- the proportion of vote each state give to the democratic candidate in the previous three presidential election , and -lrb- 2 -rrb- the number of electoral vote each state have in the Electoral College . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . furthermore , each political party can determine how many delegate to allocate to each state and territory . in 2012 for example , the democratic and republican party convention each use two different formula to allocate delegate . the Democrats base theirs on two main factor : -lrb- 1 -rrb- the proportion of vote each state give to the democratic candidate in the previous three presidential election , and -lrb- 2 -rrb- the number of electoral vote each state have in the Electoral College . in contrast , the Republicans assign to each state 10 delegate , plus 3 delegate per congressional district . 
unlike the general election , voter in the U.S. territory can also elect delegate to the national convention . furthermore , each political party can determine how many delegate to allocate to each state and territory . in 2012 for example , the democratic and republican party convention each use two different formula to allocate delegate . the Democrats base theirs on two main factor : -lrb- 1 -rrb- the proportion of vote each state give to the democratic candidate in the previous three presidential election , and -lrb- 2 -rrb- the number of electoral vote each state have in the Electoral College . in contrast , the Republicans assign to each state 10 delegate , plus 3 delegate per congressional district . both party then give fix amount of delegate to each territory , and finally bonus delegate to state and territory that pass certain criterion . 
along with delegate choose during primary and caucus , state and U.S. territory delegation to both the democratic and republican party convention also include `` unpledged '' delegate that have a vote . 
along with delegate choose during primary and caucus , state and U.S. territory delegation to both the democratic and republican party convention also include `` unpledged '' delegate that have a vote . for Republicans , they consist of the three top party official from each state and territory . 
along with delegate choose during primary and caucus , state and U.S. territory delegation to both the democratic and republican party convention also include `` unpledged '' delegate that have a vote . for Republicans , they consist of the three top party official from each state and territory . Democrats have a more expansive group of unpledged delegate call `` superdelegate '' , who be party leader and elect official . 
each party 's presidential candidate also choose a vice presidential nominee to run with he or she on the same ticket , and this choice be rubber-stamp by the convention . 
if no single candidate have secure a majority of delegate -lrb- include both pledge and unpledged -rrb- , then a `` brokered convention '' result . 
if no single candidate have secure a majority of delegate -lrb- include both pledge and unpledged -rrb- , then a `` brokered convention '' result . all pledge delegate be then `` release '' and be able to switch they allegiance to a different candidate . 
if no single candidate have secure a majority of delegate -lrb- include both pledge and unpledged -rrb- , then a `` brokered convention '' result . all pledge delegate be then `` release '' and be able to switch they allegiance to a different candidate . thereafter , the nomination be decide through a process of alternate political horse trading , and additional round of re-vote . 
=== the popular vote on Election Day === 
under the United States Constitution , the manner of choose elector for the Electoral College be determine by each state 's legislature . 
under the United States Constitution , the manner of choose elector for the Electoral College be determine by each state 's legislature . although each state currently designate elector by popular vote , other method be allow . 
under the United States Constitution , the manner of choose elector for the Electoral College be determine by each state 's legislature . although each state currently designate elector by popular vote , other method be allow . for instance , a number of state formerly choose presidential elector by a vote of the state legislature itself . 
however , federal law do specify that all elector must be select on the same day , which be `` the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November , '' i.e. a Tuesday no earlier than November 2 and no later than November 8 . 
however , federal law do specify that all elector must be select on the same day , which be `` the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November , '' i.e. a Tuesday no earlier than November 2 and no later than November 8 . today , the state and the District of Columbia each conduct they own popular election on Election Day to help determine they respective slate of elector . 
however , federal law do specify that all elector must be select on the same day , which be `` the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November , '' i.e. a Tuesday no earlier than November 2 and no later than November 8 . today , the state and the District of Columbia each conduct they own popular election on Election Day to help determine they respective slate of elector . thus , the presidential election be really a amalgamation of separate and simultaneous state election instead of a single national election run by the federal government .

=== Electoral college === 
most state law establish a winner-take-all system , wherein the ticket that win a plurality of vote win all of that state 's allocate electoral vote , and thus have they slate of elector choose to vote in the Electoral College . 
most state law establish a winner-take-all system , wherein the ticket that win a plurality of vote win all of that state 's allocate electoral vote , and thus have they slate of elector choose to vote in the Electoral College . Maine and Nebraska do not use this method , opt instead to give two electoral vote to the statewide winner and one electoral vote to the winner of each Congressional district . 
each state 's win slate of elector then meet at they respective state 's capital on the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December to cast they electoral vote on separate ballot for President and Vice President . 
each state 's win slate of elector then meet at they respective state 's capital on the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December to cast they electoral vote on separate ballot for President and Vice President . although Electoral College member can technically vote for anyone under the U.S. Constitution , 24 state have law to punish faithless elector , those who do not cast they electoral vote for the person whom they have pledge to elect .

=== election calendar === 
the typical period of the presidential election process be as follow , with the date correspond to the 2016 general election : 
spring 2015 -- candidate announce they intention to run , and -lrb- if necessary -rrb- file they statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission 
August 2015 to March 2016 -- primary and caucus debate 
February 1 to June 14 , 2016 -- primary and caucus 
April to August , 2016 -- nominating convention -lrb- include those of the minor third party -rrb- 
September and October , 2016 -- presidential election debate 
November 8 , 2016 -- Election Day 
December , 2016 -- elector cast they electoral vote 
early January , 2017 -- Congress count and certify the electoral vote 
January 20 , 2017 -- Inauguration Day

a faithless elector be one who cast a electoral vote for someone other than the person pledge or do not vote for any person .

a faithless elector be one who cast a electoral vote for someone other than the person pledge or do not vote for any person . twenty-four state have law to punish faithless elector . in 1952 , the constitutionality of state pledge law be bring before the Supreme Court in Ray v. Blair , 343 U.S. 214 -lrb- 1952 -rrb- . the Court rule in favor of state law require elector to pledge to vote for the win candidate , as well as remove elector who refuse to pledge .

Blair , 343 U.S. 214 -lrb- 1952 -rrb- . the Court rule in favor of state law require elector to pledge to vote for the win candidate , as well as remove elector who refuse to pledge . as state in the ruling , elector be act as a functionary of the state , not the federal government . therefore , state have the right to govern elector . the constitutionality of state law punish elector for actually cast a faithless vote , rather than refuse to pledge , have never be decide by the Supreme Court . while many only punish a faithless elector after-the-fact , state like Michigan also specify that the faithless elector 's vote be void .

critic also argue that the Electoral College be archaic and inherently undemocratic . with all but two state -lrb- the exception be Maine and Nebraska -rrb- use a winner-take-all system , both the democratic and the Republican candidate be all but certain to win all the electoral vote from those state whose resident predominantly vote for the Democratic Party or the Republican Party , respectively . this encourage presidential candidate to focus exponentially more time , money , and energy campaigning in a few so-called `` swing state '' , state in which no single candidate or party have overwhelming support .

critic also argue that the Electoral College be archaic and inherently undemocratic . with all but two state -lrb- the exception be Maine and Nebraska -rrb- use a winner-take-all system , both the democratic and the Republican candidate be all but certain to win all the electoral vote from those state whose resident predominantly vote for the Democratic Party or the Republican Party , respectively . this encourage presidential candidate to focus exponentially more time , money , and energy campaigning in a few so-called `` swing state '' , state in which no single candidate or party have overwhelming support . such swing state like Ohio be inundate with campaign visit , saturation television advertising , get-out-the-vote effort by party organizer , and debate . meanwhile , candidate and political party have no incentive to mount nationwide campaign effort , or work to increase voter turnout , in predominately democratic Party `` safe state '' like California or predominately Republican Party `` safe state '' like Texas . 
critic also argue that the Electoral College be archaic and inherently undemocratic . with all but two state -lrb- the exception be Maine and Nebraska -rrb- use a winner-take-all system , both the democratic and the Republican candidate be all but certain to win all the electoral vote from those state whose resident predominantly vote for the Democratic Party or the Republican Party , respectively . this encourage presidential candidate to focus exponentially more time , money , and energy campaigning in a few so-called `` swing state '' , state in which no single candidate or party have overwhelming support . such swing state like Ohio be inundate with campaign visit , saturation television advertising , get-out-the-vote effort by party organizer , and debate . meanwhile , candidate and political party have no incentive to mount nationwide campaign effort , or work to increase voter turnout , in predominately democratic Party `` safe state '' like California or predominately Republican Party `` safe state '' like Texas . in practice , the winner-take-all system also both reinforce the country 's two-party system and decrease the importance of third and minor political party .

Constitutional amendment , such as the every vote count Amendment , have be propose seek to replace the Electoral College with a direct popular vote , which proponent argue would increase turnout and participation . other propose reform include the National Popular vote Interstate Compact , a interstate compact without congressional authorization , whereby individual participate state agree to allocate they elector base on the winner of the national popular vote , instead of vote they respective statewide result . another proposal be for every state to simply adopt the District system use by Maine and Nebraska : give two electoral vote to the statewide winner and one electoral vote to the winner of each Congressional district . the Automatic Plan would replace the Electors with a automatic tally of vote to eliminate the faithless elector affect the outcome of the election . the Proportional Plan , often compare to the District Plan , would distribute electoral vote in each state in proportion to the popular vote , introduce third party effect in election outcome . the House Plan would require a constitutional amendment to allocate elector base on the House apportionment alone to lessen small state advantage . direct election plan and bonus plan have in common a higher valuation on the popular vote for president .

the Constitution give each state legislature the power to decide how its state 's elector be choose and it can be easier and cheaper for a state legislature to simply appoint a slate of elector than to create a legislative framework for hold election to determine the elector . as note above , the two situation in which legislative choice have be use since the civil war have both be because there be not enough time or money to prepare for a election . however , appointment by state legislature can have negative consequence : bicameral legislature can deadlock more easily than the electorate . 
the Constitution give each state legislature the power to decide how its state 's elector be choose and it can be easier and cheaper for a state legislature to simply appoint a slate of elector than to create a legislative framework for hold election to determine the elector . as note above , the two situation in which legislative choice have be use since the civil war have both be because there be not enough time or money to prepare for a election . however , appointment by state legislature can have negative consequence : bicameral legislature can deadlock more easily than the electorate . this be precisely what happen to New York in 1789 when the legislature fail to appoint any elector .

in 1776 , the thirteen colony , act through the second Continental Congress , declare political independence from great Britain during the american revolution . the new state , though independent of each other as nation state , recognize the necessity of closely coordinate they effort against the British . desire to avoid anything that remotely resemble a monarchy , Congress negotiate the Articles of Confederation to establish a weak alliance between the state . as a central authority , Congress under the Articles be without any legislative power ; it could make its own resolution , determination , and regulation , but not any law , nor any tax or local commercial regulation enforceable upon citizen . 
in 1776 , the thirteen colony , act through the second Continental Congress , declare political independence from great Britain during the american revolution . the new state , though independent of each other as nation state , recognize the necessity of closely coordinate they effort against the British . desire to avoid anything that remotely resemble a monarchy , Congress negotiate the Articles of Confederation to establish a weak alliance between the state . as a central authority , Congress under the Articles be without any legislative power ; it could make its own resolution , determination , and regulation , but not any law , nor any tax or local commercial regulation enforceable upon citizen . this institutional design reflect the conception of how Americans believe the depose british system of Crown and Parliament ought to have function with respect to the royal dominion : a superintending body for matter that concern the entire empire . 
in 1776 , the thirteen colony , act through the second Continental Congress , declare political independence from great Britain during the american revolution . the new state , though independent of each other as nation state , recognize the necessity of closely coordinate they effort against the British . desire to avoid anything that remotely resemble a monarchy , Congress negotiate the Articles of Confederation to establish a weak alliance between the state . as a central authority , Congress under the Articles be without any legislative power ; it could make its own resolution , determination , and regulation , but not any law , nor any tax or local commercial regulation enforceable upon citizen . this institutional design reflect the conception of how Americans believe the depose british system of Crown and Parliament ought to have function with respect to the royal dominion : a superintending body for matter that concern the entire empire . out from under any monarchy , the state assign some formerly royal prerogative -lrb- e.g. , make war , receive ambassador , etc. -rrb- to Congress , while severally lodge the rest within they own respective state government .

in 1996 , Congress attempt to enhance the president 's veto power with the Line Item Veto Act . the legislation empower the president to sign any spending bill into law while simultaneously striking certain spending item within the bill , particularly any new spending , any amount of discretionary spending , or any new limited tax benefit . in 1996 , Congress attempt to enhance the president 's veto power with the Line Item Veto Act . the legislation empower the president to sign any spending bill into law while simultaneously striking certain spending item within the bill , particularly any new spending , any amount of discretionary spending , or any new limited tax benefit . Congress could then repass that particular item . if the president then veto the new legislation , Congress could override the veto by its ordinary means , a two-third vote in both house . in Clinton v. City of New York , 524 U.S. 417 -lrb- 1998 -rrb- , the U.S. Supreme Court rule such a legislative alteration of the veto power to be unconstitutional .

== Contemporary issue == 
argument between proponent and opponent of the current electoral system include four separate but related topic : indirect election , disproportionate voting power by some state , the winner-takes-all distribution method -lrb- as choose by 48 of the 50 state -rrb- , and federalism . 
argument between proponent and opponent of the current electoral system include four separate but related topic : indirect election , disproportionate voting power by some state , the winner-takes-all distribution method -lrb- as choose by 48 of the 50 state -rrb- , and federalism . argument against the Electoral College in common discussion mostly focus on the allocation of the voting power among the state . 
argument between proponent and opponent of the current electoral system include four separate but related topic : indirect election , disproportionate voting power by some state , the winner-takes-all distribution method -lrb- as choose by 48 of the 50 state -rrb- , and federalism . argument against the Electoral College in common discussion mostly focus on the allocation of the voting power among the state . Gary Bugh ' s research of congressional debate over propose Electoral College amendment reveal that reform opponent have often appeal to a traditional version of representation , whereas reform advocate have tend to reference a more democratic view .

except in closely fight swing state , voter turnout be largely insignificant due to entrenched political party domination in most state . the Electoral College decrease the advantage a political party or campaign might gain for encouraging voter to turn out , except in those swing state . if the presidential election be decide by a national popular vote , in contrast , campaign and party would have a strong incentive to work to increase turnout everywhere . individual would similarly have a stronger incentive to persuade they friend and neighbor to turn out to vote . 
except in closely fight swing state , voter turnout be largely insignificant due to entrenched political party domination in most state . the Electoral College decrease the advantage a political party or campaign might gain for encouraging voter to turn out , except in those swing state . if the presidential election be decide by a national popular vote , in contrast , campaign and party would have a strong incentive to work to increase turnout everywhere . individual would similarly have a stronger incentive to persuade they friend and neighbor to turn out to vote . the difference in turnout between swing state and non-swing state under the current electoral college system suggest that replace the Electoral College with direct election by popular vote would likely increase turnout and participation significantly .

Historically , two doctrine concern executive power have develop that enable the president to exercise executive power with a degree of autonomy . the first be executive privilege , which allow the president to withhold from disclosure any communication make directly to the president in the performance of executive duty . George Washington first claim privilege when Congress request to see Chief Justice John Jay 's note from a unpopular treaty negotiation with great Britain . while not enshrine in the Constitution , or any other law , Washington 's action create the precedent for the privilege . 
Historically , two doctrine concern executive power have develop that enable the president to exercise executive power with a degree of autonomy . the first be executive privilege , which allow the president to withhold from disclosure any communication make directly to the president in the performance of executive duty . George Washington first claim privilege when Congress request to see Chief Justice John Jay 's note from a unpopular treaty negotiation with great Britain . while not enshrine in the Constitution , or any other law , Washington 's action create the precedent for the privilege . when Richard Nixon try to use executive privilege as a reason for not turn over subpoena evidence to Congress during the Watergate scandal , the Supreme Court rule in United States v. Nixon , 418 U.S. 683 -lrb- 1974 -rrb- , that executive privilege do not apply in case where a president be attempt to avoid criminal prosecution .

George Washington first claim privilege when Congress request to see Chief Justice John Jay 's note from a unpopular treaty negotiation with great Britain . while not enshrine in the Constitution , or any other law , Washington 's action create the precedent for the privilege . when Richard Nixon try to use executive privilege as a reason for not turn over subpoena evidence to Congress during the Watergate scandal , the Supreme Court rule in United States v. Nixon , 418 U.S. 683 -lrb- 1974 -rrb- , that executive privilege do not apply in case where a president be attempt to avoid criminal prosecution . when President Bill Clinton attempt to use executive privilege regard the Lewinsky scandal , the Supreme Court rule in Clinton v. Jones , 520 U.S. 681 -lrb- 1997 -rrb- , that the privilege also could not be use in civil suit . these case establish the legal precedent that executive privilege be valid , although the exact extent of the privilege have yet to be clearly define .

the state secret privilege allow the president and the executive branch to withhold information or document from discovery in legal proceedings if such release would harm national security . 
the state secret privilege allow the president and the executive branch to withhold information or document from discovery in legal proceedings if such release would harm national security . precedent for the privilege arise early in the 19th century when Thomas Jefferson refuse to release military document in the treason trial of Aaron Burr and again in Totten v. United States 92 U.S. 105 -lrb- 1876 -rrb- , when the Supreme Court dismiss a case bring by a former Union spy . 
the state secret privilege allow the president and the executive branch to withhold information or document from discovery in legal proceedings if such release would harm national security . precedent for the privilege arise early in the 19th century when Thomas Jefferson refuse to release military document in the treason trial of Aaron Burr and again in Totten v. United States 92 U.S. 105 -lrb- 1876 -rrb- , when the Supreme Court dismiss a case bring by a former Union spy . however , the privilege be not formally recognize by the U.S. Supreme Court until United States v. Reynolds 345 U.S. 1 -lrb- 1953 -rrb- , where it be hold to be a common law evidentiary privilege .

Jeppesen Dataplan , Inc. .

==== legislative facilitator ====

==== lack of enfranchisement of U.S. territory ==== 
Territories of the United States , such as Puerto Rico , the Northern Mariana Islands , the U.S. Virgin Islands , American Samoa , and Guam , be not entitle to elector in presidential election . 
Territories of the United States , such as Puerto Rico , the Northern Mariana Islands , the U.S. Virgin Islands , American Samoa , and Guam , be not entitle to elector in presidential election . constitutionally , only U.S. state -lrb- per Article II , Section 1 , clause 2 -rrb- and Washington , D.C. -lrb- per the twenty-third amendment -rrb- be entitle to elector . 
Territories of the United States , such as Puerto Rico , the Northern Mariana Islands , the U.S. Virgin Islands , American Samoa , and Guam , be not entitle to elector in presidential election . constitutionally , only U.S. state -lrb- per Article II , Section 1 , clause 2 -rrb- and Washington , D.C. -lrb- per the twenty-third amendment -rrb- be entitle to elector . Guam have hold non-binding straw poll for president since the 1980s to draw attention to this fact . 
Territories of the United States , such as Puerto Rico , the Northern Mariana Islands , the U.S. Virgin Islands , American Samoa , and Guam , be not entitle to elector in presidential election . constitutionally , only U.S. state -lrb- per Article II , Section 1 , clause 2 -rrb- and Washington , D.C. -lrb- per the twenty-third amendment -rrb- be entitle to elector . Guam have hold non-binding straw poll for president since the 1980s to draw attention to this fact . this have also lead to various scholar conclude that the U.S. national-electoral process be not fully democratic . 
==== favor less populous state ==== 
as a consequence of give more per capita voting power to the less populated state , the Electoral College give extra power to voter in those state .

==== prevent a urban-centric victory ==== 
proponent of the Electoral College claim the Electoral College prevent a candidate from win the presidency by simply win in heavily populated urban area . 
proponent of the Electoral College claim the Electoral College prevent a candidate from win the presidency by simply win in heavily populated urban area . this mean that candidate must make a wider geographic appeal than they would if they simply have to win the national popular vote .

the United States of America be a federal coalition which consist of component state . 
the United States of America be a federal coalition which consist of component state . proponent of the current system argue that the collective opinion of even a small state merit attention at the federal level greater than that give to a small , though numerically equivalent , portion of a very populous state . 
the United States of America be a federal coalition which consist of component state . proponent of the current system argue that the collective opinion of even a small state merit attention at the federal level greater than that give to a small , though numerically equivalent , portion of a very populous state . the system also allow each state the freedom , within constitutional bound , to design its own law on voting and enfranchisement without a undue incentive to maximize the number of vote cast . 
for many year early in the nation 's history , up until the jacksonian era , many state appoint they elector by a vote of the state legislature , and proponent argue that , in the end , the election of the President must still come down to the decision of each state , or the federal nature of the United States will give way to a single massive , centralized government . 
in he book a more Perfect Constitution , Professor Larry Sabato elaborate on this advantage of the Electoral College , argue to `` mend it , do not end it , '' in part because of its usefulness in force candidate to pay attention to lightly populated state and reinforce the role of the state in federalism .

==== isolation of election problem ==== 
some supporter of the Electoral College note that it isolate the impact of any election fraud , or other such problem , to the state where it occur .

some supporter of the Electoral College note that it isolate the impact of any election fraud , or other such problem , to the state where it occur . it prevent instance where a party dominant in one state may dishonestly inflate the vote for a candidate and thereby affect the election outcome . for instance , recount occur only on a state-by-state basis , not nationwide . critic of the current system suggest that the result in a single state -- such as Florida in 2000 -- can decide the national election and thus not keep any problem in such a state isolate from the rest of the nation . 
== proposal for reform or abolition ==

the closest the United States have come to abolish the Electoral College occur during the 91st Congress -lrb- 1969 -- 1971 -rrb- .

Representative Emanuel Celler -lrb- D -- New York -rrb- , Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee , respond to public concern over the disparity between the popular vote and electoral vote by introduce House Joint Resolution 681 , a propose Constitutional amendment which would have replace the Electoral College with simpler plurality system base on the national popular vote . 
Representative Emanuel Celler -lrb- D -- New York -rrb- , Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee , respond to public concern over the disparity between the popular vote and electoral vote by introduce House Joint Resolution 681 , a propose Constitutional amendment which would have replace the Electoral College with simpler plurality system base on the national popular vote . with this system , the pair of candidate who have receive the highest number of vote would win the presidency and vice presidency provide they win at least 40 % of the national popular vote . 
Representative Emanuel Celler -lrb- D -- New York -rrb- , Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee , respond to public concern over the disparity between the popular vote and electoral vote by introduce House Joint Resolution 681 , a propose Constitutional amendment which would have replace the Electoral College with simpler plurality system base on the national popular vote . with this system , the pair of candidate who have receive the highest number of vote would win the presidency and vice presidency provide they win at least 40 % of the national popular vote . if no pair receive 40 % of the popular vote , a runoff election would be hold in which the choice of President and vice president would be make from the two pair of person who have receive the highest number of vote in the first election .

=== National Popular vote Interstate Compact === 
several state plus the District of Columbia have join the National Popular vote Interstate Compact .

several state plus the District of Columbia have join the National Popular vote Interstate Compact . those jurisdiction join the compact agree to pledge they elector to the winner of the national popular vote . the Compact will not come into effect until a sufficient number of state agree to the Compact such that a majority -lrb- at least 270 -rrb- of all elector be pledge to the winner of the national popular vote . as of 2016 , 10 state and the District of Columbia have join the compact ; collectively , these jurisdiction control 165 electoral vote , which be 61 % of the 270 require for the Compact to take effect . 
the Compact be base on the current rule in Article II , Section 1 , clause 2 of the Constitution that give each state legislature the plenary power to determine how it choose its elector , though some have suggest that Article I , Section 10 , clause 3 of the Constitution require congressional consent before the Compact could be enforcible .
